field_edited_text.value:
VOL. XXXI, No. 24
HOPKINS REPRESENTED AT
MILWAUKEE STUDENT
CONFERENCE
•
Dr. Broadus Mitchell Takes Active Part
in Discussion; All Parts of
Country Represented

Nine delegates represented Johns
Hopkins at the Conference of the
National Council of Student Christian Associations, held in Milwaukee from December 28 to January 1. The delegates were: Dr.
Broadus Mitchell, Dr. Herbert
Schroeder, Robert Bull, C. R. Mengers, E. Foster Dowell, G. K. Reiblich, K. S. Weigh, I. Evans Rodgers, C. E. Cunningham and E. A.
Schall.
- Discuss God
'The meetings were very intertaing and abounded in argument.
The first point that was discussed
was, "Can you believe in a God in
a world like this, and if so, what
kind of a. God?" The evidence
deduced from this talk. was that the
world was a universe and that
everything on it was ordered.
The second point was that if the
world is orderly and obeys laws in
all of the different phases discussed
then the greatest reality on it is
personality.
The third point which was a natural outcome of the two preceding
discussions was that if these two
points are true, then in back of the
universe is a personal God.
Eminent Men Present

The different points were discussed by men eminent in various
walks of life who gave their opinions of the subject from different
angles such as physics, religion, social economy, and medicine. Prominent in these discussions were
Henry Sloan Coffin, Reinhard Niebuhr, Dr. Stoddard Kennedy, of
England, Dr. Mordecai Johnson,
president of Howard University,
Henry P. Van Dusen, Dr. Robert
Milliken, Harrison S. Elliot, Kirby
Page. Dr. Mitchell of this University also played a prominent part in
the discussions.
The National Council of Student
Council Associations, under whose
auspices this conference was held, is
the outgrowth of the student Y. M.
C. A.'s and Y. W. C. A.'s working
together.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 7, 1927

COTILLON CLUB
TO HOLD-DANCE
The Cotillon Club will give
a dance Saturday, January 8,
1926, from 9 to 12 P. M., in
the C. E. Hall. Music will be
furnished by the Blue Jay Orchestra. Mr. and Mrs. Norman Chase Keyes and Dr. and
Mrs. George Heberton Evans •
will chaperone the dance.
If the occasion proves a
success the dances will probably be repeated as a weekly
Saturday night occasion.
The admission as announced by the Cotillon Club
will be one dollar stag or couple.
January 7, 1927.
MILITARY OFFICE MOVES
UP TO FOURTH FLOOR
Two Rooms Are Reserved for Political
Economy Department

The Military Office has finally
moved into its new quarters on the
fourth floor of Gilman Hall, taking
over several of the rooms formerly
occupied by the Psychology Department. Moving was done during the
Christmas holidays.
The department now has three
rooms. There is a large office, taking the place of the one on the third
floor, and also offices for Major
Hoisington and Captain Strong.
The latter will also meet his classes
in his new quarters.
Student Study Hall

Mr. Otho Ryan, superintendent
of buildings, and Dr. Abercrombie
of the Physical Training Department also moved into new quarters
on the fourth floor.
Two rooms on the fourth floor,
which are being reserved for the
Political Economy Department, have
not yet been occupied. There are
two more rooms on this floor that
have not as yet been occupied.

M. COPEAU, FRENCH ACTOR
AND DRAMATIST, TO
LECTURE MONDAY

GOES TO PARIS

Prominent French Director to Speak
at C. E. Hall; Actors to Be
Entertained at Tea

WILL GIVE NINE LECTURES
To Speak on Own Research Work
Done at Hopkins
Dr. John Boswell Whitehead,
Dean of the School of .Engineering, is now in Paris and will soon
start in on his duties as Exchange
Professor to France. He sailed
from New York, as scheduled,
aboard the S. S. Paris on Monday,
December 27, Dr. Whitehead has
prepared a series of nine lectures
on "Dielectric Theory and Insulation."

Is Dramatist and Actor

At the present time, M. Copeau is
connected with the Theatre Guild in
New York and is recognized as one
of the foremost figures in contemporary French drama. He is a
leader in the movement for an artistic theatre. In 1913, after Antoine's
famous theatre had lost much of its
strength and prestige, M. Copeau
founded Le Theatre du Vieux Columbia at Paris. In this attempt he
achieved an outstanding success until the outbreak of the World War
in 1914. After the war, the theatre
was reorganized and a school for
actors started. M. Copeau is not
only a dramatist of prominence but
also an actor, having appeared in
several of his own productions.
•

DR. WHITEHEAD
LEAVES FOR FRANCE
Goes As Exchange Professor to
French Universities

M. Jean Jacques Copeau, the celebrated French dramatist and director, will speak at the Civil Engineering Hall on Monday evening. The
lecture will be given under the auspices of the Homewood Playshop,
which, because of the exceptional
popularity of its lectures, has found
it impossible to continue to hold
them in their theatre.

Paris to Be Base

Dr. John B. Whitehead

Cast to Tea

The American Exchange Professor will make Paris his base of operations but he plans to visit many
different parts of the French Republic. 'His itinerary includes most
of the foremost technical schools
of that country. He will visit the
University of Toulouse, the University of Lyons, and the University of Grenoble during the coming
winter; and the Ecolc Polytechnique, and the Ecole- Centrale on
his return to Paris. He will also
probably lecture at the University
of Lille, and the University of
Strasbourg, but these places have
not been definitely decided uPon as
yet. Dr. Whitehead expects to
spend most of his leave, extending
from January 1 to October 1, in
France, but will pass through Belgium and England on his return to
this country in September.

The Hopkins Dean is an internationally known figure in Engineering circles, having been signally
honored by the Belgian Government as well as having gained distinction in this country. He is at
present Chairman of the Committee
on Research of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, a
fellow of that Institution, Chairman
of the Committee on Electrical Insulation, of the National Research
Council, and a member of the
American Institute of Consulting
Engineers.

THE BEST YET
Even though the holidays caused a gap in University affairs
which leaves our mind A nearly perfect blank, we are unwillirm
to let slip our opportunity of congratulating the Black and Blue
Jay staff on their latest number. The College Humor number
was good—the best in fact that the Blue Jay staff has produced
during our four years' sojourn at Homewood.
Just as a cow with any sense of tradition will hang herself
enough rope, it seems that the Jay staff, if given enough
given
if
time, will put out a really clever number. Cynical as this statement may sound, it is not meant as an unkind criticism. How
undergraduates get out a comic magazine has always been beyond
us. Sitting down at a desk with copy due the next day and the
knowledge that you have got to be funny must produce an almost
incurably doleful frame of mind.
Considering this, the Jay staff has always done well. Last
month they surpassed themselves with an issue equal to the best
college comic numbers we have ever seen. The entire staff has
earned high praise, but an extra share of the glory belongs to
Bill Banks, whose drawings were the high spots of the number.

"MILWAUKEE"
From various articles in today's issue, we learn that the Hopkins delegation has returned from the conference of the National
Council of Student Christian Associations in Milwaukee. From
what we can gather the meeting was a great success. A large
number of delegates were present; several speakers of national
note were secured; and there was considerable heated and interested discussions. In addition, the delegates had a most enjoyable
time.
The conference, it is easily seen after a little reflection, represented months of planning, and a great deal Of work, time, and
money. For delegations from colleges as far from Milwaukee
as Hopkins, the last two items assume increased importance. Not
only in the case of Hopkins, but,also in that of many other colleges, we have begun to wonder if the game is worth the candle.
Interesting, even inspiring, the conference may have been, but
what, after all, was really accomplished?
As far as we know, nothing constructive, or even specific
was done. The vast majority of the delegates came with set
orthodox views; they met and decided that one should believe
In a personal God, that war is bad, and other such problems
tabled the discussion of necking and they then departed with the
very same ideas with which they arrived. There was nothing
harmful in this, some good was probably accomplished, but it did
not appear to be worth the effort.
It seems that those college students of the country who are
interested in the more serious problems of life could find a much
more profitable and constructive way of spending several days and
a considerable amount of money.
The NEWS-LETTER is pleased to announce the election of
Donald C. Niles,'27, to the position of Associate Editor; Richard
H. Wood, '29, Junior Editor; and George Glazier, '29, Assistant
Business Manager.

•

It was Dr. Mitchell's idea that

Platform." That is, he objected to

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 7, 1927

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS

SENIORS

ROYAL CLEANERS

Members of the Senior Class:
The class dues will be payable during the week of February 7th to 11th at the Barn.
As previously announced, the
amount of the dues is thirtyone dollars and fifty cents
($31:50).
This amount is determined
on the basis of collecting last
year's unpaid dues. That is,
every member who had failed
to pay last year's dues is liable
for this additional payment
which is four ($4.00) dollars.
This rule applies to the three
year men as well as the four
year members.
I trust that notice at this
date will facilitate your arrangements for prompt payment.
Very truly,
J. ALBERT ABRAHAM,
Treasurer.

2007 North Charles Street

With the Hall-Mills murder trial
still fresh in the public mind, members of the staff of The Chanticleer,
comic magazine at .Rutgers College,
expected to score a complete knockout with a "New Brunswick" number of their publication. The magazine was printed and ready for binding when the faculty gave orders
that no copies were to leave the
printing shop.
On the cover of the barred issue,
appeared a picture of "Crazy Willie
Stevens" against a background of
ben day. Willie wore a brilliant
crimson necktie and under the cartoOn appeared the caption "Our
Willie." Inside there were pictures
of Senator Simpson, the "pig woman" and the jury. Simpson was
shown prying open a case of "four
X" in an illustration entitled "Simpson Opens the Case." Jane Gibson,
the lady who kept animals that supply humanity with pork, was shown
with her mule entering the famous

Why do coeds come to college? A
hundred of the female students at
Ohio University were recently
questioned on why they had enrolled at the university. Twenty-six
claimed that they wished to enlarge
their circle of acquaintances, twentY-two were looking for a "good
tune" and fifteen said that they
Wished to escape the dullness of the
1YInne town during- the winter
months. Bored by boarding school
caused twelve to enter the college
While eight enrolled to "get collegiate. Five wanted to belong to a
sorority, five came to learn the
"Charleston" and five came to teach
it. The last named group is probably out of work at the present
time.
Strange to say, none of them
seemed to be particularly interested
in getting an educatjon.

STRICKLAND GILLILAN
SPEAKS AT ASSEMBLY
"An expert is an average man
away from home," declared Strickland Gillilan, Baltimore humorist, in
a talk at the last assembly before the
Christmas holidays. Mr. Gillilan
kept his audience in a state of continuous laughter w:th his collection
of droll sayings and subtle jokes.
In his free and easy manner of talking, he reminded one somewhat of
Will Rogers, the famous cowboy
humorist.
At the end of his talk, Mr. Gillilan recited his well-known poem,
"Off Again, On Again Finnegan,"
and related how he had written it.
'While employed on a small town
newspaper, he was confronted with
the task of filling up the paper with
reading matter. Mr. Gillilan went
out in search of news and found

VOL. XXXI, No. 24
HOPKINS REPRESENTED AT
MILWAUKEE STUDENT
CONFERENCE
•
Dr. Broadus Mitchell Takes Active Part
in Discussion; All Parts of
Country Represented

Nine delegates represented Johns
Hopkins at the Conference of the
National Council of Student Christian Associations, held in Milwaukee from December 28 to January 1. The delegates were: Dr.
Broadus Mitchell, Dr. Herbert
Schroeder, Robert Bull, C. R. Mengers, E. Foster Dowell, G. K. Reiblich, K. S. Weigh, I. Evans Rodgers, C. E. Cunningham and E. A.
Schall.
- Discuss God
'The meetings were very intertaing and abounded in argument.
The first point that was discussed
was, "Can you believe in a God in
a world like this, and if so, what
kind of a. God?" The evidence
deduced from this talk. was that the
world was a universe and that
everything on it was ordered.
The second point was that if the
world is orderly and obeys laws in
all of the different phases discussed
then the greatest reality on it is
personality.
The third point which was a natural outcome of the two preceding
discussions was that if these two
points are true, then in back of the
universe is a personal God.
Eminent Men Present

The different points were discussed by men eminent in various
walks of life who gave their opinions of the subject from different
angles such as physics, religion, social economy, and medicine. Prominent in these discussions were
Henry Sloan Coffin, Reinhard Niebuhr, Dr. Stoddard Kennedy, of
England, Dr. Mordecai Johnson,
president of Howard University,
Henry P. Van Dusen, Dr. Robert
Milliken, Harrison S. Elliot, Kirby
Page. Dr. Mitchell of this University also played a prominent part in
the discussions.
The National Council of Student
Council Associations, under whose
auspices this conference was held, is
the outgrowth of the student Y. M.
C. A.'s and Y. W. C. A.'s working
together.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 7, 1927

COTILLON CLUB
TO HOLD-DANCE
The Cotillon Club will give
a dance Saturday, January 8,
1926, from 9 to 12 P. M., in
the C. E. Hall. Music will be
furnished by the Blue Jay Orchestra. Mr. and Mrs. Norman Chase Keyes and Dr. and
Mrs. George Heberton Evans •
will chaperone the dance.
If the occasion proves a
success the dances will probably be repeated as a weekly
Saturday night occasion.
The admission as announced by the Cotillon Club
will be one dollar stag or couple.
January 7, 1927.
MILITARY OFFICE MOVES
UP TO FOURTH FLOOR
Two Rooms Are Reserved for Political
Economy Department

The Military Office has finally
moved into its new quarters on the
fourth floor of Gilman Hall, taking
over several of the rooms formerly
occupied by the Psychology Department. Moving was done during the
Christmas holidays.
The department now has three
rooms. There is a large office, taking the place of the one on the third
floor, and also offices for Major
Hoisington and Captain Strong.
The latter will also meet his classes
in his new quarters.
Student Study Hall

Mr. Otho Ryan, superintendent
of buildings, and Dr. Abercrombie
of the Physical Training Department also moved into new quarters
on the fourth floor.
Two rooms on the fourth floor,
which are being reserved for the
Political Economy Department, have
not yet been occupied. There are
two more rooms on this floor that
have not as yet been occupied.

M. COPEAU, FRENCH ACTOR
AND DRAMATIST, TO
LECTURE MONDAY

GOES TO PARIS

Prominent French Director to Speak
at C. E. Hall; Actors to Be
Entertained at Tea

WILL GIVE NINE LECTURES
To Speak on Own Research Work
Done at Hopkins
Dr. John Boswell Whitehead,
Dean of the School of .Engineering, is now in Paris and will soon
start in on his duties as Exchange
Professor to France. He sailed
from New York, as scheduled,
aboard the S. S. Paris on Monday,
December 27, Dr. Whitehead has
prepared a series of nine lectures
on "Dielectric Theory and Insulation."

Is Dramatist and Actor

At the present time, M. Copeau is
connected with the Theatre Guild in
New York and is recognized as one
of the foremost figures in contemporary French drama. He is a
leader in the movement for an artistic theatre. In 1913, after Antoine's
famous theatre had lost much of its
strength and prestige, M. Copeau
founded Le Theatre du Vieux Columbia at Paris. In this attempt he
achieved an outstanding success until the outbreak of the World War
in 1914. After the war, the theatre
was reorganized and a school for
actors started. M. Copeau is not
only a dramatist of prominence but
also an actor, having appeared in
several of his own productions.
•

DR. WHITEHEAD
LEAVES FOR FRANCE
Goes As Exchange Professor to
French Universities

M. Jean Jacques Copeau, the celebrated French dramatist and director, will speak at the Civil Engineering Hall on Monday evening. The
lecture will be given under the auspices of the Homewood Playshop,
which, because of the exceptional
popularity of its lectures, has found
it impossible to continue to hold
them in their theatre.

Paris to Be Base

Dr. John B. Whitehead

Cast to Tea

The American Exchange Professor will make Paris his base of operations but he plans to visit many
different parts of the French Republic. 'His itinerary includes most
of the foremost technical schools
of that country. He will visit the
University of Toulouse, the University of Lyons, and the University of Grenoble during the coming
winter; and the Ecolc Polytechnique, and the Ecole- Centrale on
his return to Paris. He will also
probably lecture at the University
of Lille, and the University of
Strasbourg, but these places have
not been definitely decided uPon as
yet. Dr. Whitehead expects to
spend most of his leave, extending
from January 1 to October 1, in
France, but will pass through Belgium and England on his return to
this country in September.

THE BEST YET
Even though the holidays caused a gap in University affairs
which leaves our mind A nearly perfect blank, we are unwillirm
to let slip our opportunity of congratulating the Black and Blue
Jay staff on their latest number. The College Humor number
was good—the best in fact that the Blue Jay staff has produced
during our four years' sojourn at Homewood.
Just as a cow with any sense of tradition will hang herself
enough rope, it seems that the Jay staff, if given enough
given
if
time, will put out a really clever number. Cynical as this statement may sound, it is not meant as an unkind criticism. How
undergraduates get out a comic magazine has always been beyond
us. Sitting down at a desk with copy due the next day and the
knowledge that you have got to be funny must produce an almost
incurably doleful frame of mind.
Considering this, the Jay staff has always done well. Last
month they surpassed themselves with an issue equal to the best
college comic numbers we have ever seen. The entire staff has
earned high praise, but an extra share of the glory belongs to
Bill Banks, whose drawings were the high spots of the number.

"MILWAUKEE"
From various articles in today's issue, we learn that the Hopkins delegation has returned from the conference of the National
Council of Student Christian Associations in Milwaukee. From
what we can gather the meeting was a great success. A large
number of delegates were present; several speakers of national
note were secured; and there was considerable heated and interested discussions. In addition, the delegates had a most enjoyable
time.
The conference, it is easily seen after a little reflection, represented months of planning, and a great deal Of work, time, and
money. For delegations from colleges as far from Milwaukee
as Hopkins, the last two items assume increased importance. Not
only in the case of Hopkins, but,also in that of many other colleges, we have begun to wonder if the game is worth the candle.
Interesting, even inspiring, the conference may have been, but
what, after all, was really accomplished?
As far as we know, nothing constructive, or even specific
was done. The vast majority of the delegates came with set
orthodox views; they met and decided that one should believe
In a personal God, that war is bad, and other such problems
tabled the discussion of necking and they then departed with the
very same ideas with which they arrived. There was nothing
harmful in this, some good was probably accomplished, but it did
not appear to be worth the effort.
It seems that those college students of the country who are
interested in the more serious problems of life could find a much
more profitable and constructive way of spending several days and
a considerable amount of money.
The NEWS-LETTER is pleased to announce the election of
Donald C. Niles,'27, to the position of Associate Editor; Richard
H. Wood, '29, Junior Editor; and George Glazier, '29, Assistant
Business Manager.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 7, 1927

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS

SENIORS

ROYAL CLEANERS

Members of the Senior Class:
The class dues will be payable during the week of February 7th to 11th at the Barn.
As previously announced, the
amount of the dues is thirtyone dollars and fifty cents
($31:50).
This amount is determined
on the basis of collecting last
year's unpaid dues. That is,
every member who had failed
to pay last year's dues is liable
for this additional payment
which is four ($4.00) dollars.
This rule applies to the three
year men as well as the four
year members.
I trust that notice at this
date will facilitate your arrangements for prompt payment.
Very truly,
J. ALBERT ABRAHAM,
Treasurer.

2007 North Charles Street

With the Hall-Mills murder trial
still fresh in the public mind, members of the staff of The Chanticleer,
comic magazine at .Rutgers College,
expected to score a complete knockout with a "New Brunswick" number of their publication. The magazine was printed and ready for binding when the faculty gave orders
that no copies were to leave the
printing shop.
On the cover of the barred issue,
appeared a picture of "Crazy Willie
Stevens" against a background of
ben day. Willie wore a brilliant
crimson necktie and under the cartoOn appeared the caption "Our
Willie." Inside there were pictures
of Senator Simpson, the "pig woman" and the jury. Simpson was
shown prying open a case of "four
X" in an illustration entitled "Simpson Opens the Case." Jane Gibson,
the lady who kept animals that supply humanity with pork, was shown
with her mule entering the famous
Lafayette will confer the honorlane. A panorama view of the jury ary degree of Doctor of Laws upon

Why do coeds come to college? A
hundred of the female students at
Ohio University were recently
questioned on why they had enrolled at the university. Twenty-six
claimed that they wished to enlarge
their circle of acquaintances, twentY-two were looking for a "good
tune" and fifteen said that they
Wished to escape the dullness of the
1YInne town during- the winter
months. Bored by boarding school
caused twelve to enter the college
While eight enrolled to "get collegiate. Five wanted to belong to a
sorority, five came to learn the
"Charleston" and five came to teach
it. The last named group is probably out of work at the present
time.
Strange to say, none of them
seemed to be particularly interested
in getting an educatjon.

of them smoke, according to a. recent survey. Of the thirty-five per

smoke cigarettes, 289 the pipe, while
6 confess that they take a "chaw"

STRICKLAND GILLILAN
SPEAKS AT ASSEMBLY
"An expert is an average man
away from home," declared Strickland Gillilan, Baltimore humorist, in
a talk at the last assembly before the
Christmas holidays. Mr. Gillilan
kept his audience in a state of continuous laughter w:th his collection
of droll sayings and subtle jokes.
In his free and easy manner of talking, he reminded one somewhat of
Will Rogers, the famous cowboy
humorist.
At the end of his talk, Mr. Gillilan recited his well-known poem,
"Off Again, On Again Finnegan,"
and related how he had written it.
'While employed on a small town
newspaper, he was confronted with
the task of filling up the paper with
reading matter. Mr. Gillilan went
out in search of news and found
